natural problem: What is the greatest possible product of any two distinct prime numbers less than 40?
natural solution: We look for the two largest prime numbers less than 40 and find that they are 37 and 31. The product of these two numbers is $37\times31=\boxed{1147}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q :: int
assumes h0 : "prime p"
and h1 : "prime q"
and h2 : "p < 40"
and h3 : "q < 40"
and h4 : "p ≠ q"
shows  "p * q ≤ 1147"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the greatest possible product of any two distinct prime numbers less than 40? The final Answer is 1147
 ### Proof
 We look for the two largest prime numbers less than 40 and find that they are 37 and 31. The product of these two numbers is $37\times31=\boxed{1147}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p q :: int
assumes h0 : "prime p"
and h1 : "prime q"
and h2 : "p < 40"
and h3 : "q < 40"
and h4 : "p ≠ q"
shows  "p * q ≤ 1147"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find two distinct prime numbers, each less than 40, whose product is less than or equal to 1147.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n < 40 \<and> prime n \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> m. m < 40 \<and> m ≠ n \<and> prime m \<and> n * m ≤ 1147)"
shows  "GREATEST x. \<exists> m n. m < 40 \<and> n < 40 \<and> m ≠ n \<and> prime m \<and> prime n \<and> m * n = x = 1147"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the greatest possible product of any two distinct prime numbers less than 40? The final Answer is 1147
 ### Proof
 We look for the two largest prime numbers less than 40 and find that they are 37 and 31. The product of these two numbers is $37\times31=\boxed{1147}$.
 *)

theorem
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n < 40 \<and> prime n \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> m. m < 40 \<and> m ≠ n \<and> prime m \<and> n * m ≤ 1147)"
shows  "GREATEST x. \<exists> m n. m < 40 \<and> n < 40 \<and> m ≠ n \<and> prime m \<and> prime n \<and> m * n = x = 1147"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: The statement assumes that for every prime number less than 40, there exists another different prime number also less than 40 such that their product does not exceed 1147. What is the greatest product that can be obtained from two different prime numbers less than 40? The final answer is 1147.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prime :: "nat \<Rightarrow> bool"
and max_product :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall>p. prime p \<longleftrightarrow> (p > 1 \<and> (\<forall>n. n > 1 \<and> n < p \<longrightarrow> p mod n \<noteq> 0))"
and h1 : "max_product = Max {p*q |p q. prime p \<and> prime q \<and> p < q \<and> q < 40}"
shows  "max_product = 1147"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the greatest possible product of any two distinct prime numbers less than 40? The final Answer is 1147
 ### Proof
 We look for the two largest prime numbers less than 40 and find that they are 37 and 31. The product of these two numbers is $37\times31=\boxed{1147}$.
 *)

fixes prime :: "nat \<Rightarrow> bool"
and max_product :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall>p. prime p \<longleftrightarrow> (p > 1 \<and> (\<forall>n. n > 1 \<and> n < p \<longrightarrow> p mod n \<noteq> 0))"
and h1 : "max_product = Max {p*q |p q. prime p \<and> prime q \<and> p < q \<and> q < 40}"
shows  "max_product = 1147"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the maximum product of two prime numbers where both primes are different and less than 40. The final answer is 1147.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prime :: "nat \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. prime n = (n > 1 \<and> (\<forall> m. m > 1 \<and> m < n \<longrightarrow> n mod m \<noteq> 0))"
and h1 : "\<exists> a b. a \<noteq> b \<and> prime a \<and> prime b \<and> a < 40 \<and> b < 40"
shows  "\<exists> max_product. max_product = 1147 \<and> (\<forall> a b. a \<noteq> b \<and> prime a \<and> prime b \<and> a < 40 \<and> b < 40 \<longrightarrow> a * b \<le> max_product)"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the greatest possible product of any two distinct prime numbers less than 40? The final Answer is 1147
 ### Proof
 We look for the two largest prime numbers less than 40 and find that they are 37 and 31. The product of these two numbers is $37\times31=\boxed{1147}$.
 *)

fixes prime :: "nat \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. prime n = (n > 1 \<and> (\<forall> m. m > 1 \<and> m < n \<longrightarrow> n mod m \<noteq> 0))"
and h1 : "\<exists> a b. a \<noteq> b \<and> prime a \<and> prime b \<and> a < 40 \<and> b < 40"
shows  "\<exists> max_product. max_product = 1147 \<and> (\<forall> a b. a \<noteq> b \<and> prime a \<and> prime b \<and> a < 40 \<and> b < 40 \<longrightarrow> a * b \<le> max_product)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find the largest product of two distinct prime numbers less than 40. The final answer is 1147.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q :: nat
assumes h0 : "prime p"
and h1 : "prime q"
and h2 : "p < 40"
and h3 : "q < 40"
and h4 : "p \<noteq> q"
shows  "(GREATEST x. \<exists> p q. p * q = x) = 1147"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the greatest possible product of any two distinct prime numbers less than 40? The final Answer is 1147

 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prime :: "int \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. prime n = (1 < n \<and> (\<forall>m \<in> {2..<n}. n mod m \<noteq> 0))"
and h1 : "\<exists>p q. prime p \<and> prime q \<and> p \<noteq> q \<and> p < 40 \<and> q < 40"
shows  "(\<exists>p q. prime p \<and> prime q \<and> p \<noteq> q \<and> p * q = 1147) \<longrightarrow> (\<forall>a b. prime a \<and> prime b \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a < 40 \<and> b < 40 \<longrightarrow> a * b \<le> 1147)"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the greatest possible product of any two distinct prime numbers less than 40? The final Answer is 1147
 ### Proof
 We look for the two largest prime numbers less than 40 and find that they are 37 and 31. The product of these two numbers is $37\times31=\boxed{1147}$.
 *)

and h1 : "\<exists>p q. prime p \<and> prime q \<and> p \<noteq> q \<and> p < 40 \<and> q < 40"
shows  "(\<exists>p q. prime p \<and> prime q \<and> p \<noteq> q \<and> p * q = 1147) \<longrightarrow> (\<forall>a b. prime a \<and> prime b \<and> a \<noteq> b \<and> a < 40 \<and> b < 40 \<longrightarrow> a * b \<le> 1147)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find two distinct prime numbers, both less than 40, whose product is 1147. If such a pair exists, prove that the product of any two distinct prime numbers, both less than 40, is less than or equal to 1147.
